item.title: DIY IoT door monitor with ESP8266
item.description: Using an ESP8266 for IoT projects makes me go fast while prototyping The compact format is perfect for small DIY devices Wi-Fi connectivity is built-in, and it's super affordable The ESP8266 is a low-cost Wi-Fi microchip, with a full TCP/IP stack and microcontroller capability (wikipedia) Table of Contents tldr; Requirements Circuit explanation Coding Install libraries for ESP8266 Adding the ESP8266 Board Additional libraries Flash it Try it out! Next steps REST API Web UI Demo tldr; The door monitor running in my home activates a buzzer when the proximity sensor detects that the door is opened Additionally, it creates an AP for Wi-Fi configuration using a Web interface, and can connect to a desired Wi-Fi network afterwards
item.author: (Christian Fei)

item.title: Re-examining our approach to memory mapping | Time series data, faster
item.description: What we learned by re-examining our approach to memory mapping. A low level implementation, as close as posibble to the kernel, enabled even greater performance.

item.title: Tooltips in tooltips · Philip Ardeljan is a UI designer
item.description: With the recent release of Crusader Kings 3 by Paradox Interactive, a new UI paradigm in the game stopped me in my tracks. There are a lot of lessons that web designers can learn from video game user interface design and while they aren’t always transferrable, they are worth exploring. In this case it’s the idea of having tooltips within tooltips.

item.title: Stellar Cartography With Self Organizing Maps
item.description: There was something of a family debate over whether a reduced-dimensionality starmap could still be accurate enough as to be useful, so I made a covid-quarantine experiment of it.

item.title: Tinkerer - You Aren't Going To Need It
item.description: You’re on a project. You’re developing an API to count the amount of apples in a cart. You expect to have it done, and people using it in 6 months. Obviously this API needs to be documented, after all you don’t want your consumers to have to guess how it works. You all agree, that when writing a new endpoint you’ll document it properly. Four months later it’s looking good - you have a bunch of endpoints that are beautifully documented.

item.title: Before you pack your webapp in Electron | Ori Livni’s Notes
item.description: Electron has changed the way we create desktop applications. It become very popular among start-ups and enterprises because the “easiness” of “packaging” a webapp into an “application”. But the fancy dock icon for your webapp doesn’t come free of challenges, And before you go for this solution you better know a few issues you might encounter, from my experience of 2 years building a shared codebase between a webapp and an Electron app (including native extensions).

item.title: The Business Lessons I Learned from Not Cutting My Hair for 18 Months
item.description:
This is a story of business and determination. What’s juicy about this semi-private topic is not why I haven't cut my hair for 18 months, but what I’ve learned from going through this process.
What I've experienced along the journey of letting my hair grow are business lessons that at first glance might seem trivial, but that actually reveal some profound answers to our questions about running a successful company.
Let me explain.

item.title: Music Theory is Racist
item.description:
Debate me, Ben Shapiro’s MUSIC THEORIST father who went to music school. Support this channel: https://www.patreon.com/adamneely
Thanks to Phil Ewell and his paper: https://mtosmt.org/issues/mto.20.26.2/mto.20.26.2.ewell.html
SOURCES https://bit.ly/2ZdxpMW
0:00 Introduction 2:53 Part I - The White Racial Frame of Music Theory 8:28 Part iim - North Indian Theory and Perspectives 16:52 Part IIIm7b5 - Alternative Perspectives to Western Theory 22:04 Part IVmaj7 - Music isn’t a Universal 28:24 Part V7(b9,#9,b13) - Heinrich Schenker 36:16 Part vim - Responses to Phil Ewell 40:19 Part viio - Coda
(⌐■_■)

item.title: This is definitely rare: It happens only ten times a month | The Old New Thing
item.description: Search for the phrase “Motley Fool issues rare“: “Motley Fool Issues Rare All In Buy Alert.” “Motley Fool Issues Rare Triple-Buy Alert.” “Motley Fool Issues Rare Double-Up Buy Alert.” “Motley Fool Issues Rare Double-Down Buy Alert.” “Motley Fool Issues Rare Triple-Down Buy Alert.”
item.author: (Raymond Chen Follow)

item.title: C++/WinRT injects additional constructors into each runtime class | The Old New Thing
item.description: C++/WinRT treats runtime classes similar to C# reference types. Copying a C++/WinRT runtime class copies a reference to the underlying object. You can null out the reference by assigning nullptr to it. On the other hand, C++ constructors don’t use the new keyword;
item.author: (Raymond Chen Follow)
